[[Aldabert Ricken|Ricken]] }} {{mycomorphbox | name = ''Cortinarius purpurascens'' | whichGills = emarginate | capShape = convex | hymeniumType=gills | stipeCharacter= bare | ecologicalType=mycorrhizal | sporePrintColor= brown | howEdible=edible }} {{stack end}} '''''Cortinarius purpurascens''''', also known as the '''bruising webcap''', is a [[basidiomycete]] [[mushroom]] of the genus ''[[Cortinarius]]''. The fruit bodies grow in groups on the ground in [[coniferous forest]]s, throughout the [[temperate]] zone of the [[Northern Hemisphere]], including Europe and North America. ==Taxonomy== The species was first described scientifically as ''Agaricus purpurascens'' by [[Elias Magnus Fries]] in 1818. He later transferred it to the genus ''[[Cortinarius]]'' in 1838. The species was also placed in the segregate genus ''Phlegmacium'' by [[Aldabert Ricken]] as ''P. purpurascens''. The mushroom is [[common name|commonly]] known as the "bruising webcap". ==Description== [[image:Cortinarius purpurascens 65100.jpg|thumb|left|The sticky caps may range in color from brownish to grayish blue.]] The [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] is {{convert|3|–|10|cm|in|abbr=on}} in diameter, initially convex before flattening out somewhat. The margin is rolled inward, and viscid, cuticle which is often slightly spotted, smooth and with small fugacious viscid concolorous flocci. The color varies from dirty brownish or brownish-rust to ocher or grayish bluish in the center. The margin is fibrillose (covered with roughly parallel threadlike filaments), then smooth, with a violet or reddish-violet to grayish-brown tinge, then concolorous with the center of the cap. The [[lamella (mycology)|gills]] are thin and crowded closely together, broadly emarginate (notched), dark violet when young, with edges often slightly denticulate (finely toothed). The tinge and intensity of the violet coloring is similar to that of the wood blewitt (''[[Rhodopaxillus nudus]]''). The [[stipe (mycology)|stem]] is solid, vivid violet paling to violet purple or violet brown, with a distinctly marginate bulb {{convert|3|–|4|cm|in|abbr=on}} wide, otherwise almost cylindrical towards the base. The [[wikt:cortina|cortina]] (a cobweb-like [[partial veil]] consisting of silky fibrils) is violet. The [[trama (mycology)|flesh]] is violet lilac or violet, paling slightly when mature, and with a weak, unpleasant smell and mild taste. When cut or broken it turns purple, like the gills. It is an [[edible mushroom]] of medium quality. The [[spore]]s are [[wikt:ellipsoid|ellipsoid]], slightly almond-shaped, verrucose, and measure 9–10 by 4.8–6 μm. The [[basidia]] (the spore-bearing cells) are 30–35 by 7–9 [[micrometre|μm]]. On the edge of the gills there are thin-walled irregularly bottle-shaped [[wikt:cheilocystidium|cheilocystidia]], which protrude 20–30 μm. The [[spore print|spore deposit]] is brownish rust to light brown. ==Distribution and habitat== The fruit bodies of ''Cortinarius purpurascens'' grow in groups in [[coniferous forest]]s, mainly on more acid soils and are quite rare. It is distributed throughout the [[temperate]] zone of the [[Northern Hemisphere]], and has been collected from Europe and North America. ==See also== {{Portal|Fungi}} *[[List of Cortinarius
